sentence: A generally muddled month for mutual funds in April saw one asset class soar like a selfie stick.
Diversified U.S. stock funds slipped 0.2% on average, according to Lipper Inc. data.
But China stock mutual funds notched a 14.2% gain, leading world equity funds in their 4.3% rise for the month.
"Our view for some time has been better relative opportunities exist outside the U.S.," said Russ Koesterich, global chief investment strategist for BlackRock Inc.
Despite soft manufacturing data from China, investors continue to hold out hope for further government efforts to stimulate and open up the economy.
That's feeding an insatiable appetite for Chinese A-share stocks, which trade in Shanghai.
"The A-share market appears increasingly frothy," Koesterich cautioned in an April 27 note.
He favors the H-share market, which are mainland stocks traded in Hong Kong.
Koesterich wrote: "We are not seeing the same excesses in this part of the market and valuations are much more reasonable."
As investors turned their focus away from U.S. equities, other regions also benefited.
Europe tacked on 3.5% gains and Japan 2.9%.
European and Japanese equity funds benefited from monetary easing policies and low expectations.
"It's been easier for Europe to get over a lower crossbar" relative to the U.S., Koesterich told IBD.
Russia and Brazil have had notable turnarounds from 2014.
And the sell-off in India funds last month may represent profit-taking by investors, Koesterich said.
"We still believe most investors should include emerging market equities in their portfolios," he added, noting their generally reasonable valuations.
But Koesterich warns that they may experience volatility this fall as a Fed rate hike approaches.
Emerging markets were also among bond-fund winners last month, ticking along nicely as investors sought out riskier assets in the face of lackluster economic data.
Higher interest rates and mixed earnings weighed on U.S. stocks as April drew to a close.
GDP growth in the first quarter underwhelmed investors.
Incomes in March were largely flat.

Investing In The U.S.

Several sector-fund categories managed strong gains.
Energy commodity funds rose 11.9% as oil prices rebounded.
Natural resource funds, holding energy equities, gained 8.6%.
But health/biotech funds tumbled 3.1%, hit in part by soft earnings fromBiogen ( BIIB ) and a sales miss forCelgene ( CELG ).
True,Apple ( AAPL ) posted solid results April 27.
But earnings disappointments abounded.
Companies includingProcter & Gamble ( PG ),Google ( GOOGL ),3M (MMM) andPepsiCo (PEP) struggled with a strengthening dollar that impacted overseas profits.
The rising greenback contributed to gains for small- and midcap funds' earlier this year.
"Investors were looking at those styles as a way to immunize themselves against a strong dollar," Koesterich said.
With a more domestic focus, they're less vulnerable to currency fluctuations that can impact earnings growth.
But in April, small- and midcap growth stocks -- which topped broad-based U.S. funds in Q1 -- dipped into the red.
Midcap growth funds, such as the $5.9 billion American Century Heritage Fund , averaged a 1.1% loss.
Small-cap growth funds fell 2.5%.
In contrast, large-cap growth funds were flat.
Large-cap value funds rose 1.1%.
Large-cap core funds, blending growth and value stocks, inched up 0.7%.
The pullback in smaller caps owed partly to the backup in rates.
"When real interest rates are rising, people are worried about it," Koesterich said.
"It has a bigger impact on small caps."
Large companies tend to have ready access to lenders.
But smaller businesses find it easier to borrow money to expand operations when rates are low.
The average S&P 500 fund, tracking the broad stock market , rose 0.9% last month and 1.7% in 2015 as of April-end.
Over the last 15 years, they have turned in 4% average annual gains.
Oil prices edged higher in April after a deep slump last year and early in 2015.
The gains came on the back of discord in the Middle East, a weakening dollar and production cutbacks in the U.S.
The stabilization in prices helped funds holding oil and gas commodities, and natural resource equities.
Investors also showed "some willingness to bottom-fish" given the energy sector's recent trajectory, Koesterich said.
The price of gold fell in April.
Despite that, precious metal equity funds climbed 9.4%.
Commodities precious metals funds slipped 0.5%.
Gold bugs reportedly returned to funds backed by bullion on the bet that inflation is rising.
On the tail end, real estate funds gave up 5% last month.
They're down 0.9% year to date after a healthy run in 2014.
That soft performance came as investors worried about looming rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.
Rising rates make borrowing money to fuel growth more difficult for REITs (real estate investment trusts).
Plus, their dividend yields look less attractive.
That fear -- despite the Fed's move to keep rates lower for longer -- also weighed on companies involved in producing and delivering gas, water and power.
Debt-heavy utility stocks react negatively to rising rates that increase payment burdens.
Funds tracking these equities inched up 0.8% in April and have slipped 1.9% so far this year.
Research firm S&P Capital IQ has a more favorable outlook on homegrown vs. foreign stocks.
It points to slowing economic growth in China, deflation risk in Japan, stagflation (higher living costs plus lower growth) in Brazil and weakness in most of Europe.

"In light of the outlook for the global economy, our strategy maintains overweighting domestic shares at the expense of stock markets abroad and retaining across-the-board neutrality in fixed income investments," Capital IQ's director of mutual fund research Todd Rosenbluth wrote April 17.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
